H.Res. 124 states clearly: Congress does not support the President‚Äôs transgender military ban, rejects the pseudoscience behind it & urges @DeptofDefense to continue welcoming qualified transgender Americans to enlist and serve in our U.S. military. And today it passed the House.

...deprived of medically necessary health care, or forced to compromise their integrity or hide their identity.‚Äù  http://assets2.hrc.org/files/assets/resources/56_Generals_and_Admirals_Warn_Trump.pdf¬†‚Ä¶

... As a result, the proposed ban would degrade readiness even more than the failed ‚Äòdon't ask, don't tell‚Äô policy. Patriotic transgender Americans who are serving‚Äî and who want to serve‚Äîmust not be dismissed...

...of mission-critical talent, and compromise the integrity of transgender troops who would be forced to live a lie, as well as non-transgender peers who would be forced to choose between reporting their comrades or disobeying policy.

56 retired generals and flag officers released a statement in August of 2017: ‚ÄúThe Commander in Chief has tweeted a total ban of honorably serving transgender troops. This proposed ban, if implemented, would cause significant disruptions, deprive the military...

A study commissioned by a @DeptofDefense working group in 2015 found having transgender service members would have ‚Äúminimal impact on readiness and health care costs‚Äù and ‚Äúlittle or no impact on unit cohesion, operational effectiveness or readiness.‚Äù  https://www.rand.org/news/press/2016/06/30.html¬†‚Ä¶

Don't forget: Army Chief of Staff General Mark Milley testified to the Senate Armed Services Committee on April 12, 2018 that he had ‚Äúreceived precisely zero reports of issues of cohesion, discipline, morale and all those sorts of things‚Äù regarding transgender service members.

Methylene chloride has killed dozens of people already, at least four of whom died since the draft rule was first published in January 2017. How many more need to die before this agency will do its job and protect workers from unreasonable risks?

Many retailers have already done the right thing and stopped selling these products, but Americans will continue to be exposed to this dangerous chemical until EPA moves forward with a ban that includes commercial uses.
